headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to LKQ's third quarter 2016 earnings conference call. With us today are Rob Wagman and Nick Zarcone. Please refer to the LKQ website at lkqcorp.com for our earnings release issued this morning as we
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to LKQ's third quarter 2016 earnings conference call. With us today are Rob Wagman and Nick Zarcone. Please refer to the LKQ website at lkqcorp.com for our earnings release issued this morning as well as the accompanying slide presentation for this call. 
Now let me quickly cover the safe harbor. Some of the statements that we make today may be considered forward-looking. These include statements regarding our expectations, beliefs, hopes, intentions or strategies. Actual events or results may differ materially from those expressed or implied in the forward-looking statements as a result of various factors. We assume no obligation to update any forward-looking statements. For more information, please refer to the risk factors discussed in our Form 10-K and subsequent reports filed with the SEC. 
During this call, we will present both GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures. A reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP measures is included in today's earnings release and slide presentation. 
And with that, I am happy  to turn the call over to our CEO, Rob Wagman.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Good morning, and thank you for joining us on the call today. This morning, I will begin our review with a few high-level financial metrics followed by an update on our operating segments and some macro trends we witnessed in Q3. Nick will
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe. Good morning, and thank you for joining us on the call today. This morning, I will begin our review with a few high-level financial metrics followed by an update on our operating segments and some macro trends we witnessed in Q3. Nick will follow with a detailed overview of our financial performance. 
Turning to Slide 3. Q3 revenue reached $2.39 billion, an increase of 30.3% as compared to $1.83 billion in the third quarter of 2015. Net income for the third quarter of 2016 was $122.7 million, an increase of 21.1% as compared to $101.3 million for the same period of 2015. On an adjusted basis, net income was $139.3 million, an increase of 26.8% as compared to $109.9 million for the same period of 2015. 
Diluted earnings per share for the third quarter of 2016 was $0.40, an increase of 21.2% as compared to the $0.33 for the same period of 2015. On an adjusted basis, diluted earnings per share was $0.45 in the third quarter of 2016, reflecting a 25% increase over $0.36 for the same period of 2015. 
During the quarter, we continue to witness the lingering effects of a mild winter and the headwinds of certain trends in the North American carparks. Despite these dynamics, the company delivered organic revenue growth for parts and services of 3.7%, an [indiscernible] performance compared to many companies in the global auto industry that were confronted with similar challenges and subsequently witnessed negative growth in the quarter. 
Turning to our North American organic revenue growth. During the quarter, organic revenue growth for parts and services was 2.1%, which is down from the first half of the year and below our expectations. Clearly, the macro trends in North America such as miles driven and the size of the carparks continue to trend in our favor. But in order to grow our business, the number of collisions need to grow that will then increase the demand for our collision parts. According to CCC, collision and liability-related auto claims for the first 9 months of 2016 were up only 2.4% nationally, not far from the 2.3% increase witnessed for the first 6 months of 2016. Further in that point, when looking at state levels claim data from CCC, we continue to experience large regional variations. The Northeast and Midwest regions face soft conditions, both experiencing year-over-year declines in repairable claims in certain key states. These 2 regions combined represent over 30% of our North American revenue. 
In addition, according to the U.S. Department of Transportation, miles driven in the U.S. were up 3.4% in August, a measure that also witnessed significant regional differences. During August, miles driven in the Northeast and North Central regions were up only 1.2% and 2.1%, respectively. 
Lastly, though difficult to quantify, we believe the surge in the SAAR rate over the last 3 years is initially a headwind as new vehicles tend to get new collision parts. The search also impacts our engine and transmission sales because these type of mechanical parts are covered under manufacturer's warranty. We also believe that the increase in vehicles in operation of model years 11 years and older has played a role in driving total loss rates above historical levels. Regardless of these short-term headwinds, we continue to believe that the carpark is shifting in the right direction towards our collision sweet spot of vehicles 3 to 10 model years old. In fact, the number of vehicles in that sweet spot is expected to increase by a few percentage points in 2017. 
And now turning to operations. During Q3, we purchased 70,000 vehicles for [indiscernible] by our North American wholesale operations, a 1.4% decrease over Q3 2015. Procurement costs at auctions decreased over Q3 2015 by 1.9%. 
For our North American aftermarket business, we continue to see improvements in our total collision SKU offerings as well as the total number of certified parts available, each growing 12% and 17%, respectively, year-over-year in the quarter. In our self-service retail business, during Q3, we acquired 132,000 lower-cost, self-service and crush-only cars, which is a 3.1% increase over Q3 2015. Similar to the first half of the year, we increased our self-service procurement during Q3 to take advantage of the favorable pricing for higher-quality vehicles in this line of business. 
And lastly, I am pleased with the benefits we are witnessing with our productivity initiatives. During the quarter, North America realized 60 [ph] basis points of gross margin improvement from the aftermarket procurement savings alone. And now that we are fully installed with Roadnet, our route optimization technology, we are optimistic about its potential savings. Today, 95% of our delivery routes are actively using Roadnet, and we are already witnessing some initial cost savings for stop across 49,000 daily deliveries with 3,300 trucks. During this presentation, Nick will discuss the financial impact of these initiatives in the coming quarters. 
Now moving to our European operations. In Q3, our Europe segment had organic revenue growth for parts and services of 6.7% and acquisition growth of 54.6% primarily related to Rhiag, which were offset by a decrease of 10.6% related to foreign exchange rates. During Q3, ECP drove organic revenue growth for parts and services of 6.9%. And for branches opened more than 12 months, ECP's organic revenue growth was 5.3%. During the quarter, ECP opened 3 new branches, bringing our network to 209 branches.  During Q3, collision part sales of ECP had year-over-year revenue growth of 13.2%. 
Turning to Sator. During Q3, Sator had organic revenue growth for parts and services of 5.1%. This organic revenue growth was primarily driven by the ongoing 3-step conversion and integration efforts we have put in place. 
Now on to Rhiag. Rhiag tracked in line with our expectations during the quarter. Importantly, it is mentioned on the last call, we continue to aggressively gather the necessary data and communication plan amongst our European businesses to create a targeted and sustainable pan-European procurement function. To highlight the opportunity, Sator had an existing agreement on a particular brand and product categories that Rhiag is also buying, but at a 10% higher cost. By leveraging the Sator agreement, Rhiag has budgeted its savings of EUR 200,000 annually and, again, on 1 product. 
Rhiag continues to execute on its growth initiatives and expand its footprint. During the quarter, the Rhiag team opened 8 branches in Eastern Europe. Given the growth opportunities in the market, I am happy to announce that we have an additional 14 branches scheduled for Q4. 
Now on to our Specialty segment. Our Specialty segment posted a year-over-year total revenue growth of 9.9% in the quarter, including the benefits of The Coast acquisition, and organic revenue growth of 3.7%. We believe the modest organic growth was related to the overall Specialty market facing an unfavorable mix shift as certain key product areas witnessed model year changes. Those are still relatively high. We also faced a slight reduction in the year-over-year SAAR rate during the quarter. 
Lastly, Specialty finalized the integration activities from The Coast acquisition by consolidating all of The Coast distribution and centers and sales processing into our existing network. 
And now an update on PGW. During the quarter, the PGW team secured another manufacturing renewal agreement for an existing OE platform with a new model launch. On PGW's aftermarket business, the team continues to receive industry accolades as the supplier of choice. These accolades were validated this quarter by signing an agreement with a major customer to precure an incrementally higher volume of windshields and sidelights in 2017. 
Turning to Corporate Development. In early October 2016, we acquired substantially all the business assets of Andrew Page Limited, a distributor of automotive parts in the United Kingdom. As part of this transaction, we acquired 102 Andrew Page branch locations. Andrew Page has a proud history of being a value-added supplier to the automotive repair industry in the U.K. With this acquisition, we believe that the transaction will benefit Andrew Page's customers with an extended range of products and the continuation of the exceptional level of service that their employees have historically provided. As we did expect, the U.K. Competition and Markets Authority or CMA commenced a review of the acquisition to assess whether the transaction would unreasonably lessen competition in the U.K. market. During the CMA's review, we are not allowed to integrate the business subject to certain exceptions to allow us to support key operations and there's always a risk that they may ask us to divest some or all of the business. Accordingly, until the CMA approves the transaction, we will not be able to achieve any of the projected synergies afforded by the integration of the combined businesses. We do anticipate the acquired business will continue to be modestly unprofitable during the review process. 
In addition to the Andrew Page announcement, during the third quarter of 2016, we acquired a distributor of automotive products in the Netherlands; a distributor of recreational vehicle products and accessories in the United Kingdom; a distributor of aftermarket automotive products in Ireland; and a heavy-duty truck salvage yard in Minnesota. Our acquisition strategy has always been to acquire the best assets we can with high-quality management teams and use of those strength to lever the growth of the business. As we look across our key segments, the pipeline is healthy with tremendous opportunities to grow our existing market share in key markets, expand the depth of our product lines and enter new geographic markets and, in particular, throughout Europe. 
At this time, I'd like to ask Nick to provide more detail and perspective on our financial results and our updated 2016 guidance.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rob, and good morning to everybody on the call. I'm delighted to run you through the financial summary in the quarter and, over the next few minutes, I will address the consolidated results of our company and review the performance of each of our
componenttext:
Thanks, Rob, and good morning to everybody on the call. I'm delighted to run you through the financial summary in the quarter and, over the next few minutes, I will address the consolidated results of our company and review the performance of each of our 4 segments during the third quarter before touching on the balance sheet and addressing our revised guidance for 2016. The third quarter of 2016, when taken as a whole, was an excellent quarter with revenue, segment EBITDA and adjusted EPS up 30%, 32% and 25%, respectively, when compared to the third quarter of last year. While the revenue growth in North America was a bit behind expectations, the margins in this segment were very strong. In addition, the European operations continue to perform well and the 2 big acquisitions generally performed on target. 
As Rob mentioned, consolidated revenue for the third quarter of 2016 increased 30% over last year. That reflects a 33.2% increase in revenue from parking services, partially offset by a 9.4% decrease in other revenue. The components of the parts and services revenue growth include approximately 3.7% from organic plus 32.6% from acquisitions for a constant currency growth of 36.4% before backing out the translation impact of FX, which was a 3.2% decline. I will provide a bit more detail on the organic growth of each business as I walk through the segment results. 
As noted on Page 11 of the presentation, consolidated gross margins declined 190 basis points to 37.0% due primarily to the impact of acquisitions. You will recall that both Rhiag and PGW have lower gross margins than our historical businesses. Excluding the 2 big acquisitions, gross margins were actually up about 60 basis points. 
While the consolidated gross margins were down, consolidated operating expenses as a percent of revenue were also down about 200 basis points lower than last year. Some of that reflects the impact of the different margin structure of the 2 acquisitions and some of it reflects improved efficiencies in the historical businesses. 
Segment EBITDA totaled $274 million for the quarter, reflecting a 32% increase from 2015. And as a percent of revenue, segment EBITDA was 11.5%, a 20 basis point improvement over the 11.3% recorded last year. On a year-over-year basis, we experienced a $3.8 million increase in restructuring cost related to the integration of our acquisitions. 
Depreciation and amortization was up about $26 million, mostly related to the addition of Rhiag in PGW. The same holds true for interest expense, which was up about $12 million. And with that, pretax income increased 16% in the quarter relative to last year. 
Our effective tax rate during the quarter was 31.7%, down from the 33.9% recorded in 2015. This lower rate reflects an ongoing rate of 34.75% and a $5 million benefit associated with the adoption of ASU 2016-09, which addresses tax benefits associated with stock-based compensation. All companies need to adopt this new accounting standard by the first quarter of 2017 and we have elected to adopt early. We have excluded this benefit from our adjusted EPS calculation in order to provide an apples-to-apples comparison. 
Diluted EPS for the quarter was $0.40, which was up 21% compared to last year. Adjusted EPS, again excluding restructuring charges, intangible asset amortization and a discrete tax benefit just mentioned, was $0.45 versus $0.36, reflecting a 25% improvement. Scrap had a small negative impact on earnings per share for the quarter, about half a penny, and currency fluctuations negatively impacted EPS growth by about $0.01 as well. 
As highlighted on Page 13, the composition of our revenue continues to change due to the impact of acquisitions. Since each of our segments has a different margin structure, this revenue mix shift impacts the trend in consolidated margins. This has become more accentuated with our ownership of both Rhiag and PGW, and you saw a shift in the third quarter metrics wherein North American parts and services revenue accounted for less than 40% of total consolidated revenue. 
And with that, let's get into the details on the segments. Total revenue in our North American segment during the third quarter of 2016 increased to $1,047,000,000 or about 1% over 2015. This is the combination of a 2.3% growth rate in parts and services, offset by a 9.5% decline in other revenue, the latter of which was due primarily to lower volumes and, to a lesser extent, lower prices received for a variety of metal. When looking at the North American growth, it's important to recognize that there were variations across the platform. As Rob mentioned, there were geographic differences with the central and west regions performing much better than the Northeast and Midwest regions. 
Recycling grew at faster rates than aftermarket. And even with an aftermarket, certain parts types by the core Keystone vendors, hoods and lights grew faster than some other products related to cooling or aluminum wheels. So there were positive strength and spots of weakness. 
Gross margins in North America during the third quarter of 2016 were 43.8%, a 160 basis points increase over last year. Approximately 90 basis points of the improvement relates to the aftermarket operations and the benefit of the procurement initiatives accounted for approximately 60 basis points of the 90 basis point improvement. Our salvage and self-service operations contributed 70 basis points of increase to the North American gross margins. You will note that while scrap averaged $118 a ton during Q3, in October, scrap has rolled back down to slightly below $100 a ton. 
With respect to operating expenses in our North American segment, we lost about 50 basis points of margin compared to the comparable quarter of 2015. On the upside, we continue to experience improvements in both fuel and facilities costs relative to last year. On the downside, we lost a bit of margin in personnel costs and freight expense. In total, EBITDA for the North American business during the third quarter of 2016 was $141 million. As a percent of revenue, EBITDA for the segment was 13.5% in Q3 of 2016, an increase of 110 basis points from the 12.4% reported in the comparable period of last year. 
Last call, we indicated that we expected the benefit of our productivity initiatives to pick up as we move throughout the year. As just mentioned, we saw some benefit in our cost of goods sold related to the procurement savings in connection with our aftermarket parts inventory. In addition, there are procurement benefits and other expense categories across North America. In total, we estimate the aggregate benefit of the productivity initiatives during the third quarter was approximately $8.6 million, up from the $5 million reported in Q2, or a little bit less than $0.02 a share. 
Moving on to our European segment. The total revenue in the third quarter accelerated to $770 million from $511 million, a 51% increase. Organic growth for parts and services in Europe during the third quarter was 6.7%, reflecting the combination of 6.9% growth at ECP and 5.1% growth at Sator. The impact of the acquisitions in Europe resulted in an additional 55% increase in revenue with the most significant amount reflecting the addition of Rhiag. So on a constant currency basis, European parts and services revenue was up 61%. These constant currency increases were offset by an 11% decline due to the translation impact of the strong dollar, particularly relative to the pound sterling. As you can see on Page 19, the average rate during the quarter was about 15% below last year and the sterling was at $1.30 at quarter end. More recently, the sterling has fallen a further 7%, down to $1.22, and the euro is also down about 3% to $1.09. The translation impact of these latest drops will lay on our reported U.S. dollar results for the rest of the year, probably to the tune of about $0.01 in the fourth quarter. 
Gross margins in Europe were 36.2%, a 210 basis point decline from the comparable period of last year, largely reflecting the impact of Rhiag. As mentioned in prior calls, Rhiag has a lower gross margin structure than either ECP or Sator. During Q3, Rhiag had a gross margin of about 33.5%, which reduced the consolidated European gross margin by about 150 basis points. Excluding the impact of Rhiag, gross margins decreased 60 basis points primarily due to ECP, which experienced an increase in customer rebates and the impact of some of the incremental cost of the new distribution facility in Tamworth rolling through cost of goods sold. 
With respect to operating expenses as a percent of revenue, we experienced a 150 basis points improvement on a consolidated European basis. We benefited from a 240 basis point reduction in operating expenses due to the addition of Rhiag, which has lower operating expenses as a percent of revenue than ECP or Sator. Offsetting these gains was an 80 basis point increase in facility and warehouse expense, reflecting some of the cost of the Tamworth facility as well as new branches and hubs at ECP. In addition, we lost about 30 basis points of margin in the U.K. related to the impact of translation losses on inventory purchases, which are denominated in a foreign currency. 
With respect to the Tamworth project, the incremental costs related to this project in the third quarter were approximately GBP 2 million or about $2.6 million. Again, some of this was recorded in cost of goods sold and some in SG&A. In total, it reflects a 30 basis point impact on European margins. 
European EBITDA totaled $73 million, a 38% increase over last year, reflecting a solid performance at ECP and Sator and the positive impact of Rhiag. As a percent of revenue, European EBITDA margins in the third quarter were 9.4% versus 10.3% last year, a 90 basis point decline, again 30 basis points of which relates to the Tamworth project. 
Turning to our Specialty segment. Revenue for the third quarter totaled $313 million, a 10% increase over the comparable quarter of last year. The organic growth rate was 3.7%, while the impact of the acquisition of Coast in August of 2015 added 6.2% to revenue growth. In the last couple of calls, we indicated that the high level of organic growth in Specialty was not sustainable and overall, we were happy with the third quarter growth rate. 
Gross margins in our Specialty segment for the third quarter were flat compared to last year as the impact of stocking 2 new Specialty distribution centers in Michigan and Washington state, which were not in operation at this time last year, was offset by an increase in the advertising credits. 
Operating expenses as a percent of revenue in Specialty were down about 100 basis points. Facility expense increased to certain costs related to the 2 new distribution centers just mentioned. But on the plus side, we continue to see SG&A leverage from integrating the acquisitions into our existing network as well as the benefit of the lower fuel prices. 
EBITDA for Specialty was $32 million in the quarter, up 24% from the third quarter of last year. And as a percent of revenue, EBITDA for the Specialty segment increased 120 basis points to 10.4% in 2016 compared to 9.2% last year. Remember, this is a highly seasonal business and you should assume these margins will decline as we move through the historically soft Q4 period. 
On Page 22, you can see the impact of the acquisition of PGW. Revenue for the quarter was $259 million, while gross margins in Q3 were 22.6%, which is very consistent with the expectations we highlighted at the time the transaction was announced. EBITDA margins for PGW were 10.7% in the third quarter. 
Let's move on to capital allocation. As presented on Slide 23, you will note that our after-tax cash flow from operations during the first 9 months was approximately $524 million as we experienced strong cash earnings and only a moderate increase in working capital. During the first 9 months of 2016, we deployed a little bit more than $1.9 billion of capital to support the growth of our businesses, including $153 million to fund capital expenditures and about $1.8 billion to acquire businesses. We closed the quarter with approximately $272 million of cash, of which $226 million was held outside of the U.S. And we had roughly $3.3 billion of total debt outstanding. So our net debt was approximately $3 billion. And on a pro forma basis, taking into account the impact of acquisitions, our net leverage was a little bit less than 2.7x latest 12 months EBITDA. At quarter end, the total availability under our credit facility was approximately $1.2 billion, which we believe is more than sufficient to support the continued growth of our business.  
Finally, as noted in our press release, we have provided updated guidance on some of our key financial metrics for 2016. As relates to the organic growth for parts and services, we reduced the organic growth guidance for full year 2016 to 4.5% to 5%, reflecting the 5.1% rate for the first 9 months and an expectation that we don't anticipate any major movements during the fourth quarter. For those trying to back into the Q4 growth, the range implies a 2.6 to 4.6 growth rate. But it is important to note that there is 1 less business day in Q4 of 2016 than Q4 of 2015, and while that may sound trivial, it's 1.5% fewer business day compared to last year. Customers don't buy more on other days to make up the difference, so the calendars simply puts us in a 1.5% [ph] hold to start. In addition, the hurricane earlier this month closed some of our operations and some of our customers' operations in Florida and the Carolinas for a couple of days. 
Our range for adjusted EPS, which excludes the after-tax impact of intangible amortization and the tax benefit of adopting ASU 2016-09, is $1.78 to $1.84 per share with a midpoint of $1.81. As in the past, we have narrowed the range to reflect the fact that we are 9 months through the year. The new range reflects the fact that Q3 results were right on track, and the outlook for the core business for the rest of the year is largely unchanged, except for the anticipated headwinds from currencies, lower scrap prices and the dilutive impact of owning Andrew Page as a completely independent company without the ability to integrate operations. To be clear, the new EPS guidance assumes pound sterling and euro exchange rates of $1.22 and $1.09, respectively, and importantly, that scrap remains at current levels as well. 
Our assumed tax rate for 2016 remains at 34.75%, excluding the benefit of adopting the new accounting pronouncement. 
Our current guidance for cash flow from operations also narrowed a bit to approximately $575 million to $600 million, and the guidance for capital spending is unchanged at $200 million to $225 million. 
At this point in time, I'll turn the call back over to Rob to wrap up

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nick. As a company, we are always focused on financial performance, but we are equally focused on facing change head on and rapidly adapting in order to continuously deliver positive results for our stockholders, employees and most importantly, ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Nick. As a company, we are always focused on financial performance, but we are equally focused on facing change head on and rapidly adapting in order to continuously deliver positive results for our stockholders, employees and most importantly, our customers. There is no question that weather impacted various lines of business and many markets for our company thus far in 2016, a similar scenario to what we witnessed in 2012. We firmly believe that like 2012, this impact is temporary and that the macro trends continue to present opportunities for all of our segments. Yet we don't rest on our laurels and simply blame softness in our business or uncontrollable circumstances. Rather, during those periods, we strive to maintain our historical growth rates and our leading positions by focusing on what we can control such as the margin improvements we recognized in this quarter. It is clear as headwinds present themselves, our team of nearly 41,000 employees globally actively adjust to market conditions to effectively and profitably manage their businesses, not only for today, but to position us well for the future. This focus allowed us again to deliver double-digit EPS growth in the midst of a challenging environment. So a big thank you for the LKQ team. 
And with that, operator, we are now ready to open the call for the questions.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from the line of Ben Bienvenu from Stephens Inc.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about some of the performance disparity in the CCC numbers across geography persisting into 3Q. That's a little bit surprising, I guess, with the thought that maybe the impact from weather would be less substantial in 3Q across the markets. May
componenttext: You talked about some of the performance disparity in the CCC numbers across geography persisting into 3Q. That's a little bit surprising, I guess, with the thought that maybe the impact from weather would be less substantial in 3Q across the markets. Maybe your thoughts as to why there is that disparity still in 3Q despite what I would think would be a little bit less impacted weather period?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Benjie. Yes, we certainly looked into that with the CCC and with some of our customers. What we find is that the vast majority of collisions are drivable collisions, so they do tend to take time to get repaired when the customer is ready to get th
componenttext: Thanks, Benjie. Yes, we certainly looked into that with the CCC and with some of our customers. What we find is that the vast majority of collisions are drivable collisions, so they do tend to take time to get repaired when the customer is ready to get the car to the shop. So it does kind of drag on through the entire year, actually, with the drivable collision. And then you look at just the overall claims volume being up just 2.4% for the whole year. There's just been a light amount of claims being filed this year. It's just been a really soft year, but it's carried through all of Q3.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ben. This is Nick. Think about the map of the United States. I'm going to give you some names of the states where claims volume was down year-over-year: Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan
componenttext: Yes, Ben. This is Nick. Think about the map of the United States. I'm going to give you some names of the states where claims volume was down year-over-year: Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan and Indiana. The only big state missing there in that [indiscernible] New Jersey and Illinois. New Jersey was up 0.5% and Illinois was up 2/10 of a percent. So that whole Northeast and Midwest section of the country just had lower claims volume.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one other area, too, Ben, that we saw was weak was Western Canada. The decimation of the fracking industry up there, our claims volume's down, way down there as well as our business. So it's not just weather. It's some economic conditions as well.
componenttext: And one other area, too, Ben, that we saw was weak was Western Canada. The decimation of the fracking industry up there, our claims volume's down, way down there as well as our business. So it's not just weather. It's some economic conditions as well.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Interesting. That's really helpful color. And then shifting gears to the Andrew Page business. It looks like some of the numbers that we've looked at, actually, the sales productivity per store is pretty great. But it sounds like maybe operationally, they
componenttext: Interesting. That's really helpful color. And then shifting gears to the Andrew Page business. It looks like some of the numbers that we've looked at, actually, the sales productivity per store is pretty great. But it sounds like maybe operationally, they're underperforming and not particularly profitable stores. Just curious as to what best practices you can bring there to that business to improve the profitability of the stores? And then ultimately, what you think the contribution could be from that chunk of stores.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Unfortunately, under the hold separate order we're not allowed to integrate the businesses. But we do believe purchasing will be the biggest benefit. We tend to buy a little bit better than they do. We are under a hold separate order allowed to sell
componenttext: Sure. Unfortunately, under the hold separate order we're not allowed to integrate the businesses. But we do believe purchasing will be the biggest benefit. We tend to buy a little bit better than they do. We are under a hold separate order allowed to sell to each other so we are supporting the business today. But until we can fully integrate the business, when we do integrate the business, it will be logistics. We believe we have a much [indiscernible] with Tamworth 2 coming online, we're going to be able to much better support those businesses with inventory and deliveries, which we think will make a huge operational benefit for those stores that they have.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just to be clear, Ben, that business was sold get. It basically went into receivership and we bought it at basically through a prepackaged bankruptcy process to give you the U.S. analogy, if you will. So obviously, the performance of the business was
componenttext: Yes. Just to be clear, Ben, that business was sold get. It basically went into receivership and we bought it at basically through a prepackaged bankruptcy process to give you the U.S. analogy, if you will. So obviously, the performance of the business was headed down by the time we got assets. We do think there is an ability by adequately stocking their warehouses and their stores to actually try revenue back north to where it was to tweak their financial issues.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one last thing on the CMA. We are close to filing our submission for the CMA. They have up to 2 months to decide what the next steps are. So when we get released, we'll be ready to start integrating the business hopefully by Q1.
componenttext: And just one last thing on the CMA. We are close to filing our submission for the CMA. They have up to 2 months to decide what the next steps are. So when we get released, we'll be ready to start integrating the business hopefully by Q1.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Craig Kennison with Mary.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Craig Kennison with Mary.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to probe the North American business a little further. Could you explain how much of that business is tied to collision trends versus mechanical trends?
componenttext: I wanted to probe the North American business a little further. Could you explain how much of that business is tied to collision trends versus mechanical trends?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the salvage business or the recycling business, Craig, is roughly a 50-50 split. The aftermarket business is almost wholly collision focused. So when you look at it in its entirety, out of our total revenue, on a consolidated global basis, slightly les
componenttext: So the salvage business or the recycling business, Craig, is roughly a 50-50 split. The aftermarket business is almost wholly collision focused. So when you look at it in its entirety, out of our total revenue, on a consolidated global basis, slightly less than 30% of our revenue is collision based.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then Rob, you mentioned statistics from CCC that claim volume was up only 2.4%. That sounds like a decent number. Could you give us some context to that? What was that figure in the full year of 2015, for example?
componenttext: That's helpful. And then Rob, you mentioned statistics from CCC that claim volume was up only 2.4%. That sounds like a decent number. Could you give us some context to that? What was that figure in the full year of 2015, for example?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll get that. We're looking for that right now, Craig. I just want to state that I know in 2012, we had very similar results to what we're seeing this year. In 2013, it did bounce back. And we believe to some of those macro trends that we're seeing, new
componenttext: We'll get that. We're looking for that right now, Craig. I just want to state that I know in 2012, we had very similar results to what we're seeing this year. In 2013, it did bounce back. And we believe to some of those macro trends that we're seeing, new car sales are definitely a little bit of a headwind at first as I mentioned in my prepared remarks, also starting to come out of R&D, so we do expect some help there. We did mention on the call the increase in total losses. The good news is there that CCC is anticipating that will start to level up now because of the newer carpark getting into the system. And, of course, the regional segmentation that we're seeing, as Nick mentioned, the Northeast and the Midwest just really getting decimated by claims volume. So we opened the normal winter, but we do expect it obviously to bounce right back.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as you look for that number, if I can just slip in a quick question on Europe and the margin there. I know it's under pressure due to the mix of some of the new businesses that you've acquired, but what do you think that margin can settle over time at
componenttext: And as you look for that number, if I can just slip in a quick question on Europe and the margin there. I know it's under pressure due to the mix of some of the new businesses that you've acquired, but what do you think that margin can settle over time at the gross margin levels as you exact purchasing synergies?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we were at 36 2 in the quarter last quarter, we are at 37 4. Some of that is just seasonal differences, Craig. So the gross margin, you figure with the addition of Rhiag, I think, I mentioned in my comments, Rhiag was around 33.5% gross margins. So
componenttext: Well, we were at 36 2 in the quarter last quarter, we are at 37 4. Some of that is just seasonal differences, Craig. So the gross margin, you figure with the addition of Rhiag, I think, I mentioned in my comments, Rhiag was around 33.5% gross margins. So that's what's pulling it down from historical levels. We would hope to get a percent or 2 from procurement over time. That's a hard process. The vendors are not anxious to just give it big discounts, but we're working at it very hard. John and his team over in London, they've got a dedicated group that's focused on nothing but trying to execute a pan-European procurement program.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Craig, the number you're looking for, we'll circle back to you. We'll get in touch with CCC on that.
componenttext: Craig, the number you're looking for, we'll circle back to you. We'll get in touch with CCC on that.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from James Albertine with Consumer Edge.
componenttext: And your next question comes from James Albertine with Consumer Edge.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask just as a point of reference, I know you are a few months, maybe a quarter or 2 out from the CMA process, kind of fulfilling its duties. But if we were to look at prior integration of something like Unipart, would that be a good proxy for
componenttext: I wanted to ask just as a point of reference, I know you are a few months, maybe a quarter or 2 out from the CMA process, kind of fulfilling its duties. But if we were to look at prior integration of something like Unipart, would that be a good proxy for us to think about with respect to dilution initially and then sort of the opportunity overtime with Andrew Page?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Andrew Page, we got actually earlier in the process. By the time that Unipart actually kind of went out, the stores were basically bacon. Andrew Page, the stores were ongoing. We had inventory -- depleted inventory, but inventory in the stores, that'
componenttext: Yes. Andrew Page, we got actually earlier in the process. By the time that Unipart actually kind of went out, the stores were basically bacon. Andrew Page, the stores were ongoing. We had inventory -- depleted inventory, but inventory in the stores, that's where we're rebuilding and the like. So we do think, however, that we will be able to get Andrew Page back to profitability. It's probably going to make us for a penny to a penny and a half in the fourth quarter. And so we would look in 2017 once we're able to kind of fully work with their team, get the customer service levels where they need to be particularly the fulfillment levels and inventory's back at the right levels, we can grow revenue and that would hop [ph] the profitability as well. We'll take some cost savings just related to procurement, some back office stuff, maybe a little bit on the logistics. But we do think we can drive it back into profitability, which will obviously help the overall margins.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jamie, unfortunately, with the hold separate, we can't really dig into the locations at this point. So initially, our focus will be on purchasing logistics in the back office functions.
componenttext: Yes, Jamie, unfortunately, with the hold separate, we can't really dig into the locations at this point. So initially, our focus will be on purchasing logistics in the back office functions.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. That's helpful. And a quick question, if I may, on Pittsburgh Glass. Congratulations on the new customer you signed up on the aftermarket side. I just want to understand sort of what that can do to your margin if we kind of look forward just
componenttext: Okay, great. That's helpful. And a quick question, if I may, on Pittsburgh Glass. Congratulations on the new customer you signed up on the aftermarket side. I just want to understand sort of what that can do to your margin if we kind of look forward just sort of -- maybe I'm asking for a reminder on the OE versus aftermarket contribution to gross margin. And then a point of clarification. We understand that PGW is your only business exposure to OEMs directly. Is that true? Or is there another business channel or sub channel that we're missing with respect to OEs directly?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll answer that question, but Nick, take the margin question. Jamie, it is the 1 exposed to OE the most. We have a little bit of exposure on the KAO side with the accessories side because we do see that as new car sales are up, we do well on the accessor
componenttext: I'll answer that question, but Nick, take the margin question. Jamie, it is the 1 exposed to OE the most. We have a little bit of exposure on the KAO side with the accessories side because we do see that as new car sales are up, we do well on the accessories side, but it's sort of a secondary issue there. But the OE business is the only one that has true cyclicality to the OE production.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jamie, this is Nick. As you can imagine, the gross margin profile of the aftermarket business and the OE business are very different. Operating costs are as well since there is no real distribution in selling expense related to the OE business. But i
componenttext: Yes, Jamie, this is Nick. As you can imagine, the gross margin profile of the aftermarket business and the OE business are very different. Operating costs are as well since there is no real distribution in selling expense related to the OE business. But in order of magnitude, the ARG gross margins are in well north of 30% where the OE margins are in the mid-teens.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. So it sounds like it will be a mixed benefit based on the fact that you're adding aftermarket customer, if I heard you correctly?
componenttext: Okay, great. So it sounds like it will be a mixed benefit based on the fact that you're adding aftermarket customer, if I heard you correctly?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Exactly.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Sam Darkatsh with Raymond James.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Sam Darkatsh with Raymond James.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, if you had it in your prepared remarks and I missed it, I apologize. Within your North American parts and services organic growth, the 2.1%, can you parse out volumes versus price mix in that?
componenttext: Nick, if you had it in your prepared remarks and I missed it, I apologize. Within your North American parts and services organic growth, the 2.1%, can you parse out volumes versus price mix in that?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We got benefits from both. The pricing was slightly more than the volume impact. That doesn't mean we were necessarily increasing prices across the board set. As I've mentioned, I think, last quarter, some of -- a good portion of the price increase c
componenttext: Yes. We got benefits from both. The pricing was slightly more than the volume impact. That doesn't mean we were necessarily increasing prices across the board set. As I've mentioned, I think, last quarter, some of -- a good portion of the price increase comes from just selling a newer part and the mix shift as to what parts we're selling. And so it may come across in looking like we're taking prices up, but it just had to do with that we're selling a slightly more expensive part. But again, slightly more than half of the growth was price related.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two more quick questions. And I guess, one of them is more critical than the other. The first would be, I mean, with the increase in total losses, I recognize that it's a smaller percentage of the overall claims versus repairable claims. But with the incr
componenttext: Two more quick questions. And I guess, one of them is more critical than the other. The first would be, I mean, with the increase in total losses, I recognize that it's a smaller percentage of the overall claims versus repairable claims. But with the increase in total losses, does that have the threat of either overwhelming or offsetting the advantages who have with the SAAR sweet spot over the next few [ph] years?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think so, Sam. Don't forget, we like total losses because that's where we get our inventory from as well. So there's still 82% of the cars that are in accidents are getting repaired. So I see that as a wash, actually, although a fewer cars are bei
componenttext: I don't think so, Sam. Don't forget, we like total losses because that's where we get our inventory from as well. So there's still 82% of the cars that are in accidents are getting repaired. So I see that as a wash, actually, although a fewer cars are being repaired. But they tend to be older cars as what CCC is telling us. So they are totally an older car, which makes sense because the average model year is up to 11.5 model years old. But the SAAR is much more important to us, getting new cars into the system because the new car is going to be fully insured. And that's why I'm pretty bullish on 2017. We're getting these 1 to 3-year cars out of warranty into our sweet spot. So we'd like to see a strong SAAR rate by far.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Last quick question. Obviously, Germany made some news with respect to the resolution trying to ban combustion engine production over time. I know it's a long-tailed item and it's far export from even being industry standards. But how does that affect you
componenttext: Last quick question. Obviously, Germany made some news with respect to the resolution trying to ban combustion engine production over time. I know it's a long-tailed item and it's far export from even being industry standards. But how does that affect your business longer-term, ROB, if it does become kind of the world we live in?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: If it's a shift to electric vehicles, that's a little bit more of a problem. If it's going to be more diesel, actually, that's actually a positive. Diesel engines sell for far more than what we get for a gas engine, actually. So depending on where it goes
componenttext: If it's a shift to electric vehicles, that's a little bit more of a problem. If it's going to be more diesel, actually, that's actually a positive. Diesel engines sell for far more than what we get for a gas engine, actually. So depending on where it goes, I was actually in China last week and they are having similar initiatives over there as well. But nobody seemed concerned about it, the people we talked to. So it's a long tail as you said.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Nate Brochmann with William Blair.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Nate Brochmann with William Blair.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I so wanted to talk to just [indiscernible] North American issues a little bit. But, one, just wondering if you have any thoughts in terms of the fact that the miles driven were up and the claims were less in terms of being up. I get the disparity acro
componenttext: So I so wanted to talk to just [indiscernible] North American issues a little bit. But, one, just wondering if you have any thoughts in terms of the fact that the miles driven were up and the claims were less in terms of being up. I get the disparity across regions and whatnot, but usually, those have a little bit of a tighter correlation in terms of why those claims wouldn't follow directly with the miles driven. And then second part of that, in terms of going into next year, obviously, Rob, you've been very bullish in terms of, hey, assuming a normal winter, we have easy comps or easier comps. In theory, we should be back to that 5% to 7% North American positive as organic growth rate. Is there anything underlying the surface, assuming again a normal winter and things kind of go back like they did in 2013? Anything underlying the surface that you would think would be such a use of potential headwind when we wouldn't get there?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: When I look at some of the normal weather conditions, as I said, we were getting cars starting to come into the sweet spot. There's a lot of macro good tailwinds for us in terms of miles driven, the carpark for our KAO business, normal winter will certain
componenttext: When I look at some of the normal weather conditions, as I said, we were getting cars starting to come into the sweet spot. There's a lot of macro good tailwinds for us in terms of miles driven, the carpark for our KAO business, normal winter will certainly spur our glass business as well. I don't see any major headwinds that can impact that other than another mild winter on top of easy comps as you said. It just feels like there's enough positive tailwinds behind us that are going to make 2017 look like 2013.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I mean, I haven't heard of anything, but no underlying shifts or anything that we might not be seeing that your customers are saying in terms of something going on that we wouldn't be thinking of?
componenttext: Okay. So I mean, I haven't heard of anything, but no underlying shifts or anything that we might not be seeing that your customers are saying in terms of something going on that we wouldn't be thinking of?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing that we've heard from our customers, interestingly enough, is that they're having a hard time hiring technicians. And just getting the work out the door has been a little bit of a challenge for that side of the business. But that, they will
componenttext: The only thing that we've heard from our customers, interestingly enough, is that they're having a hard time hiring technicians. And just getting the work out the door has been a little bit of a challenge for that side of the business. But that, they will fix. They will find people to fix the cars, I'm absolutely convinced of that. So no, nothing underlying that we're hearing from our customer base whatsoever.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, two, talked about obviously controlling what you can of the margin side. Kudos for delivery that and it still feels that we're kind of in the relative early innings in terms of seeing the result as you pointed out, Nick, sequentiall
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, two, talked about obviously controlling what you can of the margin side. Kudos for delivery that and it still feels that we're kind of in the relative early innings in terms of seeing the result as you pointed out, Nick, sequentially, so it continues to go well. Anything else on the topline, though, that you do to help your cause in terms of whether it's trying to buy more cars or we talked before about getting in a transmission remanufacturing business? Or anything on the incremental side of trying to just push incrementally on the sales effort?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. We did mention that we've been trying to buy a better car in anticipation of these newer cars coming into the sweet spot. So we will be pushing more cars into the system, absolutely. That is our goal. We're in the process of acquiring more pro
componenttext: Absolutely. We did mention that we've been trying to buy a better car in anticipation of these newer cars coming into the sweet spot. So we will be pushing more cars into the system, absolutely. That is our goal. We're in the process of acquiring more property wherever we can to process more vehicles. So that is absolutely a focus as well as introducing new product types. We talked about the number of certified parts continue to go up, preparing a much stronger level of those parts as well. So I think our inventory is going to be well-positioned to meet the organic growth needs that we have.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just last question, Rob, just because you brought up in terms of hiring technicians. Is there anything going on in the -- underlying again in the surface where the cars are becoming so complex and the diagnostics is so complex that any worr
componenttext: Okay. And then just last question, Rob, just because you brought up in terms of hiring technicians. Is there anything going on in the -- underlying again in the surface where the cars are becoming so complex and the diagnostics is so complex that any worry you have passed the warranty period that more cars, whether it's a collision or mechanical repair would be going back to the dealer for some reason?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. I talked obviously to the MSOs quite regularly on their thoughts on that, and they don't believe that the technology is not insurmountable for a technician not trained in the body shop -- in the dealership environment. So they are confid
componenttext: I don't think so. I talked obviously to the MSOs quite regularly on their thoughts on that, and they don't believe that the technology is not insurmountable for a technician not trained in the body shop -- in the dealership environment. So they are confident as you can see by their acquisitions, they continue to acquire companies. They think they are well positioned to be able to handle those repairs. More importantly, I think, is our manufacturer's ability to replicate those parts over in Taiwan and they're seeing no issues whatsoever acquiring the correct aluminum or the high-strength steels. So no issues on either side.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay me. Other thing is even after more cars added in the dealer collision repair shops, that doesn't mean that there's more OE parts because the insurance companies are still mandating which parts are going to be used. Just the week before last, I actual
componenttext: Okay me. Other thing is even after more cars added in the dealer collision repair shops, that doesn't mean that there's more OE parts because the insurance companies are still mandating which parts are going to be used. Just the week before last, I actually spent a day with customers out in the field including dealers, and they basically said that they don't have the ability to slot the parts being used. The insurance companies are driving it all. So it doesn't make a difference where the repair is being held and done. The choice of parts are actually still being driven by the insurance companies.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Bret Jordan with Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Bret Jordan with Jefferies.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question, I guess, you've given the CCC number on repairable claims growth year-to-date of 2.4. What's the total claim so we can factor in the losses? Because obviously, some of the salvage auction guys are seeing more volume flowing through theirs insura
componenttext: Question, I guess, you've given the CCC number on repairable claims growth year-to-date of 2.4. What's the total claim so we can factor in the losses? Because obviously, some of the salvage auction guys are seeing more volume flowing through theirs insurance companies opt not to repair. But what's the total crash rate?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's about 6%, which includes comp, which are flood losses, tornadoes. So yes, the auctions are getting that benefit, those cars that don't get repaired because of the floods and pale damage, severe pale damage to the total the car.
componenttext: It's about 6%, which includes comp, which are flood losses, tornadoes. So yes, the auctions are getting that benefit, those cars that don't get repaired because of the floods and pale damage, severe pale damage to the total the car.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, on Andrew Page, 102 stores, assuming its finally approved, we many of those do you think you will need be to close? Is there a lot of duplicate real estate there with the ECP?
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, on Andrew Page, 102 stores, assuming its finally approved, we many of those do you think you will need be to close? Is there a lot of duplicate real estate there with the ECP?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. There is, however -- they got a unique customer base so we're going to look at that on a neutral basis. But as it stands right now, we're planning on keeping the vast majority open because they have a service to different customers to certain a extent
componenttext: No. There is, however -- they got a unique customer base so we're going to look at that on a neutral basis. But as it stands right now, we're planning on keeping the vast majority open because they have a service to different customers to certain a extent and the brand is so strong. We'll look at that post PMA clearance.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one last question on Specialty. I think you said you're pretty happy with 3.7% growth. Where do you see that being? And I guess, when you acquired the original Keystone, it was sort of seeing as growing in line with the core North American
componenttext: Okay. And then one last question on Specialty. I think you said you're pretty happy with 3.7% growth. Where do you see that being? And I guess, when you acquired the original Keystone, it was sort of seeing as growing in line with the core North American business at the time. I guess, now that we owned it for a couple of years, is there something you should think is a lower single-digit grower? Or is it the change in the mix as you bought Stag and Coast that has brought the growth down into a low to mid-single as opposed to a mid- to upper single?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two to 3 quarters were actually above the North American growth and I think that's going to continue, Brett. I think that the volume continues to be strong. The RV sales were up year-over-year, so as long as that continues, we do expect decent organic gro
componenttext: Two to 3 quarters were actually above the North American growth and I think that's going to continue, Brett. I think that the volume continues to be strong. The RV sales were up year-over-year, so as long as that continues, we do expect decent organic growth in that line of business.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, for the first 9 [ph] months, the organic growth in Specialty was 7.3%.
componenttext: Yes, for the first 9 [ph] months, the organic growth in Specialty was 7.3%.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And, I guess, from the competitive landscape and Specialty, do you see anything changing in our -- obviously, Amazon is talking about auto parts these days, our favorite topic recently, and Specialty and performance is a category they are focusing o
componenttext: Okay. And, I guess, from the competitive landscape and Specialty, do you see anything changing in our -- obviously, Amazon is talking about auto parts these days, our favorite topic recently, and Specialty and performance is a category they are focusing on. Do you see any change? Are they making inroads, or is it pretty much status quo from your customer base?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Status quo. Amazon is a big bulky part, as you know. They have not shown any desire at this point to stock a lot of that product. So at this point, our customer base are still very strong coming direct to us.
componenttext: Yes. Status quo. Amazon is a big bulky part, as you know. They have not shown any desire at this point to stock a lot of that product. So at this point, our customer base are still very strong coming direct to us.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Bill Armstrong with the CL King.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Bill Armstrong with the CL King.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the North American 2.1% growth, are you seeing any disparity or divergence between mechanical versus collision repair?
componenttext: On the North American 2.1% growth, are you seeing any disparity or divergence between mechanical versus collision repair?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: As Nick mentioned in his prepared remarks, our core parts business did well. But what we saw a little bit of softness, Bill, was in the wheel business and the collision cooling business and obviously a little bit of paint that's tied to the collision itse
componenttext: As Nick mentioned in his prepared remarks, our core parts business did well. But what we saw a little bit of softness, Bill, was in the wheel business and the collision cooling business and obviously a little bit of paint that's tied to the collision itself. So the mechanical side did okay in the salvage side of the business.

componenttext: Yes, Bill. The FX is likely going to hit us for $0.01, maybe slightly more than $0.01. We think the scarp is going to hit us for at least half a penny, maybe a little bit more. As I mentioned, Andrew Page will likely hit us close to a penny and a half, and that's really the sum and substance to the slight tweaks to the guidance.

componenttext: No, not at all, Jason. The OEs are still doing the same thing they've done and have increased their price matching programs whatsoever. It's interesting. On the [indiscernible] competition, we are obviously active acquirers in the business and we obviously get to see financials, and we're seeing the industry struggle. They don't seem to be taking market share from anybody, our competition, so -- from the financials we've seen.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned weather. I mean, is this more of a function of the economy, just consumers not repairing their cars, as you say, drivable collisions?
componenttext: You mentioned weather. I mean, is this more of a function of the economy, just consumers not repairing their cars, as you say, drivable collisions?

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's definitely part of it. There's certainly some economic uncertainty out there with the elections going on, that's for sure. Yes, when the car is drivable, the consumer can elect to pocket that check that they get from their insurance company. It is
componenttext: That's definitely part of it. There's certainly some economic uncertainty out there with the elections going on, that's for sure. Yes, when the car is drivable, the consumer can elect to pocket that check that they get from their insurance company. It is interesting when we've done our channel checks on that, Jason. We don't -- the insurance companies never know if the car actually got repaired. It's pretty interesting. When they write a check to third party, that customer can either the car or honestly take the money. They would not know unless there was a supplement, in other words, they wrote an estimate for $1,000, shops said they need $1,200 they would know obviously because they have to write an additional check. But the vast majority of the time, insurance doesn't even if the car got repaired.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then finally, just looking at the collision revenue number in the U.K., up 13%, which is so strong, but maybe up a little from historical growth rates. Just wondered if you can talk about that business and your efforts to increase the benefit there.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Still very pleased with our collision growth there, double digit. They do have mild winter, and it's also been similar to the United States, the influx of new cars. Registrations are up dramatically in the U.K. So they're getting a little bit of a he
componenttext: Yes. Still very pleased with our collision growth there, double digit. They do have mild winter, and it's also been similar to the United States, the influx of new cars. Registrations are up dramatically in the U.K. So they're getting a little bit of a headwind from the new car. Again, it tends to get new parts. They are also coming out of that in the next year, so we think the tailwind is start to emerge with the car parking a little bit more on the sweet spot. So the same number of insurance companies in our program. Very consistently happy with the results we've been delivering, and no one's been turning their backs us is in terms of stopping the programs. We are starting our initial -- just an update on the continent, we're talked about bringing the collision parts to the continent. We're just starting our initial cost with some of the Netherlands insurance companies to start rigging collision parts into that market as well. So we anticipate 2017 being a launching of that program as well.

headline: LKQ Corp., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And before we wrap up the call, I just want to make one thing clear, because there was some analysts who put out notes this morning before the call with the implicit or the implication that the change on the accounting standard, the benefit of lower tax r
componenttext: And before we wrap up the call, I just want to make one thing clear, because there was some analysts who put out notes this morning before the call with the implicit or the implication that the change on the accounting standard, the benefit of lower tax rates got rolled into our adjusted EPS. That's incorrect. Adjusted EPS of $0.45 excludes the benefit of the adoption of the new accounting standards. So if we had just let it roll through, we would have reported $0.47. Likewise, our guidance for the year excludes the benefit of the new accounting standards.
